title: Maro Itoje fires warning to New Zealand ahead of Rugby World Cup semi-final
text:
Maro Itoje has served notice to New Zealand that England are ready to end their generation-long dominance of world rugby on Saturday - boldly declaring: 'We're going to get them.'

The Saracens lock has experienced success against the mighty All Blacks with the Lions and now he is convinced that he and his team-mates can take down the sport's pre-eminent nation in Yokohama.

Itoje has developed a winning habit with club and country and the 24-year-old is adamant that England can claim the Kiwi scalp in Saturday's semi-final.

Maro Itoje has played in three of England's four games at the 2019 Rugby World Cup in Japan

Itoje will start at second-row alongside Courtney Lawes against New Zealand on Saturday

Asked about the Lions tour in 2017, which ended in a 1-1 series draw, he said: 'I learned a lot about New Zealand, their culture, how they play the game, how good and clinical they are - and how to get them.

'This weekend feels like the time we're going to get them. The feeling I get is that we're coming together at just the right time. I look at the quality of our team, our coaching and our support staff and it gives me immense confidence.'

Itoje enhanced his soaring reputation on that last Lions tour - notably with a command performance as the tourists won the second Test in Wellington, leaving thousands of delirious British and Irish fans chanting his name after the final whistle.

Itoje was outstanding for the Lions against the All Blacks in their own backyard in 2017

He joked that 'they could make an opera about that game' and described it as a 'good day', but insisted that he won't rely on that glorious memory to enhance his innate belief.

'Quite honestly, even if I hadn't experienced beating them, I'd still have that same confidence,' he said. 'My confidence doesn't derive from the 2017 Lions tour. They are different teams and different circumstances. My confidence derives from the personnel we have and what we are capable of.

'I have never ever gone into a game thinking that team is going to beat me. The way I see New Zealand, I respect what they have done but I don't see them as a team that is going to beat us.

'They are a very good team and they have the capacity to do some very dangerous things, but I still believe that if we play our best rugby, we will win.'

Itoje also agreed that any side wanting to be considered the best in the world really has to conquer the All Blacks, as if it is a rite of passage in international rugby.

'As Ric Flair (WWE wrestling champion) said, "To be the man, you've got to beat the man". If you want to be the best, you've got to beat the best. That is our challenge. That is what is in front of us.'
description: CHRIS FOY IN YOKOHAMA: Itoje has experienced success against the mighty All Blacks with the Lions and now he is convinced that he and his team-mates can take down New Zealand.
authors: Chris Foy For The Daily Mail
